title: Mam found in suitcase on Arkansas farm was a WWII vet
title_page: Mam found in suitcase on Arkansas farm was a WWII vet | Daily Mail Online
text:
An 89-year-old man whose body was discovered in a large suitcase on a rural Arkansas farm was a Second World World War veteran from New York, police have revealed.
War hero Robert Brooks died of natural causes at his home about a month before his body was discovered in a Prairie County field.
Two carers, Virginia Colvin and Michael Stivers, have been charged with abuse of a corpse after allegedly driving 19 hours to dispose of the body.
Police are investigating whether someone covered up Mr Brooks's death was hidden so that they could claim his Social Security payments.
Virginia Colvin and Michael Stivers were charged with abuse of a corpse and could face 10 years in prison
Lt David Gilbo of the police department in Johnstown, New York told the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette: 'He was a war hero who could have been buried at the [Arlington] National Cemetery. Instead, he ends up in a suitcase dumped in a field in Arkansas.'
Police said Brooks, who was just 4ft 11in tall, wasn't dismembered.
Gilbo said authorities will not be extraditing the suspects to New York because of Arkansas' strict laws on abuse of a corpse.
In New York, the offense is punishable by three years in prison, while in Arkansas it is punishable by 10 years.
Brooks served in the military and was a gunner in a B-17 bomber's ball turret.
'It's the most dangerous assignment in war,' Prairie County Sheriff Rick Hickman said. 'The belly gunner is in a small bubble on the bottom of the plane. The enemy wants to shoot at him first. Life expectancy on that job is very short.'
